metadata.title: An intuitive guide to confidence intervals | by Sahil Gupta | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: An intuitive guide to confidence intervals
metadata.description: Statistics is based on data that we observe. The underlying data generation process is assumed to be random and one of the goals of statistical modeling is to understand this data generation process…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: distribution in the process of converging to the true parameter

all_paragraphs: Statistics is based on data that we observe. The underlying data generation process is assumed to be random and one of the goals of statistical modeling is to understand this data generation process. As the data itself is random, any numbers we estimate based on this observed data has some inherent uncertainty linked to it. One way to think about this is that if we collected the data again and tried to estimate the number again, the result can probably change. In other words, the estimate is variable (think: variance). Due to this, we are usually not interested in single values (or point estimates), rather a range of values, which is a natural way to talk about an estimate that we are uncertain of. In statistical parlance, this is called a confidence interval. In simple words, confidence intervals let us quantify our uncertainty about an estimate in the form of a range of values.

I have studied confidence intervals in the past and never felt satisfied with my understanding. Every time, I was left with a fuzzy feeling that I understood what confidence intervals meant, but never feeling sure. Recently, I found some enlightenment and in this article, I will be talking about confidence intervals using theory and simulations.

Before diving deep into the details, let’s check our understanding of confidence intervals. Take a look at this article and the plot on whether Americans were wearing masks or not in public in response to coronavirus spread. As per the data, 84% of Americans wore a mask in public with a margin of error (or confidence interval) of +/- 2.6% points. Let’s assume, for the sake of this discussion, that they are talking about a 95% confidence interval, as that is a fairly common choice. Here’s a question for you,
Q: Does this mean that the interval [81.4%, 86.6%] contains the actual percentage of people who wore a mask in public 95% of the time?
If you answered yes to the above question, then you are making a common interpretation mistake around confidence intervals just like the old me.
Let’s start by refreshing our memory about what exactly are confidence intervals.

In the mask example above, α = 0.05 (95% confidence), the parameter θ = percent of Americans who wore a mask in public in response to the virus spread, and a = 81.4%, b = 86.6%, which were both calculated using the collected data. In other words, the above equation states that the probability that the (true) parameter is contained (/trapped) in the interval C is at least 1-α. Notice, how I silently added the word true in front of the word parameter in the above sentence. This is the crux of confidence intervals, i.e. θ represents the true parameter value, which is unknown (otherwise the survey is useless), but is deterministic. More explicitly, the percentage of total Americans who wore a mask in public as coronavirus spread is not known, but it’s not a random number. If we had the willpower and means to survey all Americans, we could find this unknown (deterministic) number.

Surveying the entire population of Americans is not realistic and we want to make some reasonable guesses with the data we collected. Basically, with confidence intervals, we are trying to come up with a range of values that would contain the true proportion of Americans wearing masks 95% of the time. Notice, the uncertainty in the confidence interval creeps in through the endpoints of the interval ‘a’ and ‘b’, which are a function of data (which is assumed to be random!).
Takeaway: confidence intervals talk about the probability of a random interval containing (unknown) deterministic true parameter.

A natural interpretation of confidence intervals can be as follows: imagine repeating the experiment over and over (in this context, this would mean doing several independent surveys). For each experiment, we can compute the confidence interval containing the true (unknown) parameter. By the law of large numbers, 95% of the time the (random) interval will contain the true parameter. This happens because we can represent the event that an interval contains the true parameter by an indicator function, and then the proportion of 0.95 follows from LLN.
Now, let’s look at an example from the book All of Statistics to gather these concepts.

Let θ be a fixed, unknown real no. and let X₁, X₂ be independent random variables such that P(Xᵢ=1)=P(Xᵢ=-1) = 0.5. Let Yᵢ = θ + Xᵢ, and suppose we only observe Y₁, Y₂. Define the following “confidence interval”, which contains only one point,
Let’s look at a realization of this experiment. Suppose we observe Y₁ = 15 and Y₂ = 17. Based on this data, our 75% confidence interval is C={16}.

This computed confidence interval does not say that the probability of ‘C’ containing θ is 75%. Rather, as θ is fixed (see the question), it is either contained in the confidence interval or not. We are given that θ is unknown. If (magically) we came to know the value of θ, we could have explicitly observed whether it is contained in the interval (P(θ ∈ C) = 1), or not (P(θ ∈ C) = 0). In other words, there is nothing uncertain about a fixed (or deterministic) value: it is either in the interval or not (eg. P(2 < 3) = 1).

A Common Pitfall: after observing the data and computing the confidence interval with level ‘1-α’, it is no longer the case that the probability of true parameter being contained (/trapped) in this interval is at least 1-α. The interval either contains the true parameter or not. As confidence interval is a random variable, it’s value based on data is a realization, which represents a 1-α confidence level, and is no longer probabilistic. When we call an interval an x% confidence interval, the “x%” is associated with the reliability of the estimation procedure (the process of calculating ‘a’ and ‘b’).

This seems a bit weird because we never get to see the true parameter θ (feels like it would be random), but remember that it is assumed to be deterministic. This notion follows from the frequentist interpretation which says that as θ is a deterministic unknown number, it can’t be random.

The graphic summarizes what we talked about in the previous sections: we observe some data (which is random), based on which we calculate a confidence interval for a given level (α), and this results in a 1-α confidence interval, which is a realization and hence is not probabilistic. Moreover, there is an unknown deterministic true value of the parameter, which either lies in ‘C’ or not (just like the number 2 either lies in the interval [3,4] or not). Finally, when we say [a,b] is a 1-α confidence level, “1-α” a label from the estimation procedure and doesn’t aim at any probabilistic statements around containing the true parameter θ. In essence, the above machinery consumes the data (and α) and spits out an interval ‘C’, which we like to call 1-α confidence level that is completely deterministic.

One big question that might be lingering in your mind can be how would we ensure that the true parameter is trapped in an interval ‘C’ without ever knowing its actual value? It might seem like magic (at least it did to me), but it’s based on the idea of a very powerful theorem central to all of the statistics: Central Limit Theorem (more on this in the next section). I have left out the estimation of confidence intervals as it deserves a separate discussion.

In this section, let’s look at a simulation using an example similar to the mask data. Suppose we surveyed a group of Americans (whether they wore a mask or not) and observed the following responses: X₁, X₂, …, Xn, where

This is an indicator variable indicating whether a person wearing a mask (1) or not (0), with a probability p. Further, assume that these are i.i.d. which means that Xᵢ~ Bern(p) are Bernoulli random variables. Similar to the earlier discussion, the true proportion p is unknown. One idea to estimate p can be to take the average of our data, i.e.,

This seems like a natural estimator: we compute the proportion of people in our sample that wore a mask. As explained earlier, this estimate is variable in the sense that if the data changes, p_hat can change. Quantitatively, the law of large numbers and central limit theorem tells us the following,

Provided certain assumptions are satisfied, both these laws together talk about convergence to the true parameter value and the distribution in the process of converging to the true parameter (provided n is large enough). So, we can be sure that our estimate converges to the true value. Now, let’s focus on the confidence interval. As an aside, we can observe that the variability associated with our estimate is p(1-p)/n, which goes to zero as we collect responses from more and more people.
For this exercise, let’s focus on a 95% confidence interval. Using the above equation, we can write this,
This gives us a way to contain the true parameter p,

Here, “qₓ” is the quantile function and equal to ~ 1.96. The last step follows from the fact that we want the probability that ‘C’ contains the true parameter to be at least 1-α. Using this value, we get,

There’s still a small problem: the whole point of this exercise was to estimate p which is unknown, but our expression for ‘C’ contains p. There are several ways to proceed, but to keep this article concise, let’s proceed with a simple conservative bound, i.e. the maximum width of the interval. This occurs for p = 0.5. So, we obtain
We will now use this final expression for the simulations. For the simulations below, I assumed that n = 1000, which is reasonable in the context of surveying people.

We can observe that as the number of experiments (which is another way of saying that we are doing the experiment over and over again) increases, the proportion of confidence intervals that contain the true parameter converges to the level 1-α (here α=0.05). We can also see that for a small number of experiments only one confidence interval didn’t contain the true parameter, which might seem contrary to the level 0.95 we used for this analysis. But, we need to remember that the 30 confidence intervals that we see in the left-most plot are 30 realizations, which were drawn from the underlying distribution of confidence intervals that has some variability. If you try re-running the simulations for the same number of experiments, this is why it spits out different results each time. This is also exactly why we say that once we estimate the confidence interval using the observed data, it is no longer probabilistic. Now, there might be a possibility that our estimated confidence interval doesn’t contain the true parameter (for example, if we had selected the 1 red confidence interval from the left-most plot), but that is exactly what we capped with the analysis at the start of this section. Although we haven’t removed the possibility completely, we made is highly unlikely like any probabilistic analysis.
You can find the script used for these simulations here.
